content.description: Start on jugs, and get your feet established. Progress up and right on good holds until you reach the summit of the triangular shaped southwest face, then rock over either side.
content.location: Start on the left side of the Southwest face of the boulder. This is around the tree on the right side of the slab.

content.description:
Interesting crossover moves on a slightly overhanging face, with good feet.

Sit start on Jugs below the starting holds for the West Arete, and trend up and to the right across the face until you can rock over the right side.
content.location: southwest face of the boulder, this is the low traverse.

content.description:
Climb on the arete on the right side of the southwest face. Trend up and left until reaching the top of the triangular face.

Contrived, as you could top out at any time on this climb.
content.location: southwest face, right side, grab the arete.

content.description:
Starting on good crimps on the left side of the Falling Ant Boulder, traverse left until you're in a tree, then top out. The holds get better as you traverse farther left.

Grabbing the top of the boulder is off route, and would kind of defeat the purpose of this problem.
content.location: North side of the falling ant boulder

content.description: Highly enjoyable easy slab climbing leads to the top of this route. Friendly crimps!
content.location: Falling Ant Slab's right side of the slab. To the left of a tree.

content.description: Locate the blankest part of the falling ant boulder and climb it using a surprising lack of holds. Climbing this problem in old school boots would be an impressive feat! Smears and microcrimps will get you to the top of the hardest pure slab problem the Jenny Lake Boulders have to offer.
content.location: This is the left route described on the hand drawn topo at the ranger station. The traverse route starts further left, but this is the left most independent line.

content.description: Climb the center of falling ant slab, straight to the top.
content.location: Center of the falling ant slab.

content.description: Directly in front (Jenny Lake side) of the Falling Ant Slab is a 6' tall boulder with a bunch of jugs on it. Great problem for a kid, or just to do for fun (which I thought it was). Climb up this thing any old way you care to!
content.protection: as much or as little as you deem safe
content.location: On the boulder directly in front of the Falling Ant Slab
